elements.content: The properties recently reported on the Cu­(I)-iodide pyrimidine nonporous 1D-coordination polymer [CuI­(ANP)] n (ANP = 2-amino-5-nitropyridine) showing reversible physically and chemically driven electrical response have prompted us to carry a comparative study with the series of [CuX­(ANP)] n (X = Cl (1), X = Br (2), X = CN (4), and X = SCN (5)) in order to understand the potential influence of the halide and pseudohalide bridging ligands on the physical properties and their electrical response to vapors of these materials. The structural characterization of the series shows a common feature, the presence of −X–Cu­(ANP)–X– (X = Cl, Br, I, SCN) double chain structure. Complex [Cu­(ANP)­(CN)] n (4) presents a helical single chain. Additionally, the chains show supramolecular interlinked interactions via hydrogen bonding giving rise to the formation of extended networks. Their luminescent and electrical properties have been studied. The results obtained have been correlated with structural changes. Furthermore, the experimental and theoretical results have been compared using the density functional theory (DFT). The electrical response of the materials has been evaluated in the presence of vapors of diethyl ether, dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP), CH2Cl2, HAcO, MeOH, and EtOH, to build up simple prototype devices for gas detectors. Selectivity toward gases consisting of molecules with H-bonding donor or acceptor groups is clearly observed. This selective molecular recognition is likely due to the 2-amino-5-nitropyridine terminal ligand.

Additionally, the chains show supramolecular interlinked interactions via hydrogen bonding giving rise to the formation of extended networks. Their luminescent and electrical properties have been studied. The results obtained have been correlated with structural changes. Furthermore, the experimental and theoretical results have been compared using the density functional theory (DFT). The electrical response of the materials has been evaluated in the presence of vapors of diethyl ether, dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP), CH2Cl2, HAcO, MeOH, and EtOH, to build up simple prototype devices for gas detectors. Selectivity toward gases consisting of molecules with H-bonding donor or acceptor groups is clearly observed. This selective molecular recognition is likely due to the 2-amino-5-nitropyridine terminal ligand.

elements.content: A series of halo and pseudohalo Cu­(I)-pyridinato double chains with 2-amino-5-nitropyridine as terminal ligand have been prepared, and their luminescent and electrical properties were studied. The structural flexibility of these chains allows physically and chemically driven electrically response for these materials. We have evaluated the detection of vapors of several organic volatile molecules of some of these coordination polymers. The results show selectivity toward molecules containing H-bonding donor/acceptor groups.

The results show selectivity toward molecules containing H-bonding donor/acceptor groups.

elements.content: The production of polymers based on the combination of metal ions and ligands (organic or inorganic) is an appealing area of research for both the basic chemistry aspects and the production of novel multifunctional and dynamic materials. Indeed, in recent years development of coordination polymers (CPs) with a large variety of architectures showing a combination of physicochemical properties, such as luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, and electrical conductivity, has dramatically grown. As a result promising applications in gas separation or storage, heterogeneous catalysis, and drug delivery have been suggested. More recently, some CPs have shown the ability to produce dynamic structures in which an external physical or chemical stimulus produce a response in their properties. This feature is related with the structural flexibility of the ligands and/or the capacity of the coordination sites to exchange/release/reaccommodate molecules. Therefore, CPs can be considered as a novel source of stimuli-responsive materials with potential applications as chemical switches, memories, or molecular sensors. However, research in this area is still very limited and has been essentially focused on magnetic response materials toward either a physical or a chemical stimulus. Some 1D-CPs have been developed as potential source of molecular wires. Thus, quasilinear physical properties have been reported for MX and MMX chains (M = transition metal, X = halide), some of them showing Peierls-like transitions with temperature affecting their electronic, magnetic, and/or conducting properties. Additionally, double stranded CuI-halide stairs have shown interesting physical properties. 1D-CPs based on Cu2X2 have recently shown flexible structures that enable reversible physically driven electrical conductivity transitions at almost room temperature and chemically driven transitions by supramolecular interactions with molecules that induce a dramatic enhancement of the electrical conductivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The production of polymers based on the combination of metal ions and ligands (organic or inorganic) is an appealing area of research for both the basic chemistry aspects and the production of novel multifunctional and dynamic materials. Indeed, in recent years development of coordination polymers (CPs) with a large variety of architectures showing a combination of physicochemical properties, such as luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, and electrical conductivity, has dramatically grown. As a result promising applications in gas separation or storage, heterogeneous catalysis, and drug delivery have been suggested. More recently, some CPs have shown the ability to produce dynamic structures in which an external physical or chemical stimulus produce a response in their properties. This feature is related with the structural flexibility of the ligands and/or the capacity of the coordination sites to exchange/release/reaccommodate molecules. Therefore, CPs can be considered as a novel source of stimuli-responsive materials with potential applications as chemical switches, memories, or molecular sensors. However, research in this area is still very limited and has been essentially focused on magnetic response materials toward either a physical or a chemical stimulus. Some 1D-CPs have been developed as potential source of molecular wires. Thus, quasilinear physical properties have been reported for MX and MMX chains (M = transition metal, X = halide), some of them showing Peierls-like transitions with temperature affecting their electronic, magnetic, and/or conducting properties. Additionally, double stranded CuI-halide stairs have shown interesting physical properties. 1D-CPs based on Cu2X2 have recently shown flexible structures that enable reversible physically driven electrical conductivity transitions at almost room temperature and chemically driven transitions by supramolecular interactions with molecules that induce a dramatic enhancement of the electrical conductivity.

elements.content: In a recent review article, we have detected that studies focused on electrical properties in materials based on coordination polymers with organic ligands containing functional groups with molecular recognition capability via hydrogen bonds are still very scarce. Indeed, few systems containing metallo-macrocycles, a coordination polymer, and just two extended systems with sulfur ligands as linkers have been reported. In this context, our group has recently studied a few systems containing modified nucleobases with interesting properties. The exceptional features recently reported for [CuI­(ANP)] n (3) (ANP= 2-amino-5-nitropyridine) () have prompted us to extend these studies to the corresponding series of halo and pseudohalo derivatives [CuX­(ANP)] n (X = Cl (1), X = Br (2), I (3), CN (4), and SCN (5)). The direct reactions carried out between Cu­(I) or Cu­(II) salts and ANP have allowed us to isolate and characterize 1D-coordination polymers based on Cu–X–Cu chains. Note that although there are several similar Cu2X2 chains reported, including six with the same double Cu2I2 ladder topology, no studies on their electrical conductivities have been reported to date, except for those performed by us.

elements.content: These materials have shown the coexistence of luminescence and electrical conductivity. Moreover, the amino and nitro groups are able to undergo supramolecular interactions through hydrogen bonds giving rise to molecular recognition with other complementary molecules, providing an added value toward potential assembly for complex systems such as nucleic acids, implementing their use in molecular electronics. Interestingly, we have observed that, in some of the 1D-chains, temperature slightly affects the 1D-CP structure, changing dramatically the electrical conductivity, and additionally, the terminal ligand ANP can act as an antenna for gas detection. The electrical response of compounds 2 and 3 has been studied by exposing them to vapors of different solvents including diethyl ether, dimethyl methylphosphonate, CH2Cl2, HAcO, MeOH, and EtOH. Compound 3 shows a better response than 2, and interestingly, both compounds 2 and 3 show selectivity toward solvents with H-bonding donor groups.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

2-Amino-5-nitropyridine (ANP = C5H5N3O2), CuI2, CuBr2, CuCl2⋅2H2O, CuCN, Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, NH4SCN, and the solvents were purchased from standard chemical suppliers and used as received. [Cu(ANP))I] n  (3) was prepared following the procedure already reported.

elements.content: IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer spectrum 100 spectrophotometer using a universal ATR sampling accessory and on a Bruker FT-IR Vector 22 model in the range 4000–400 cm–1 with KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were carried out by the microanalytical service of the Autónoma University of Madrid.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction were collected on polycrystalline samples filled in 0.5 mm glass capillaries that were mounted and aligned on an X’Pert PRO θ/2θPANalytical diffractometer with primary monochromator and detector with fast X’Celerator (or an Empyrean PANalytical diffractometer, for 3) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 77 Å). The samples have been analyzed with scanning θ/2θ.

elements.content: Preliminary direct current (dc) electrical conductivity measurements were performed on different single crystals of compounds 1–5, with carbon paint at 300 K and two contacts. The contacts were made with wolframium wires (25 μm diameter). The samples were measured at 300 K applying an electrical current with voltages from +10 to −10 V. The measurements were performed in the compounds along the crystallographic a axis.

elements.content: The thermal dependence of the dc electrical conductivity was measured with the four (or two, depending on the size of the crystals) contact methods on several (at least four) single crystals of compounds 1–5 in the temperature range 50–400 K. In those cases (compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5) where the resistance at room temperature exceeded the detection limit of our equipment (5 × 1011 Ω), we performed the study in the temperature range 300–400 K. The contacts were made with Pt wires (25 μm diameter) using graphite paste. The samples were measured in a Quantum Design PPMS-9 equipment connected to an external voltage source (Keithley model 2400 source-meter) and amperometer (Keithley model 6514 electrometer). All the conductivity quoted values have been measured in the voltage range where the crystals are Ohmic conductors. For those crystals where the resistivity at room temperature was too high to be measured, the quoted values were extrapolated from the Arrhenius law with the data at high temperatures. The cooling and warming rates were 0.5 and 1 K/min.

elements.content: The influence of different solvent vapors on the electrical conductivity measurements for compounds 2 and 3 was measured on different pressed pellets of thickness ranging between 0.7 and 1 mm. Each powder sample (around 20 mg) was pressed by applying ca. 6 Tons/m2 to form pellets with an area close to 0.25 cm2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data were collected using an Autolab electrochemical system II PGSTAT30 (Ecochemie, The Netherlands) impedance analyzer over the frequency range from 1 Hz to 1 MHz with an applied voltage of 0.01 V. All measurements were collected using a two-probe method. Alternating current measurements through path were performed to determine the conductivity parameters.

elements.content: The samples were exposed to acetic acid, CH2Cl2, diethyl ether, dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP), MeOH, EtOH in the vapor phase for different times (15 min and 1, 14, 24, and 70 h). After exposition, the pellets were allowed to stay in the air for 30 min and 1 h in order to remove the adsorbed solvent molecules. At least three different pellets for each experiment were tested in order to corroborate the reproducibility of the measurements.

elements.content: Luminescence excitation and emission spectra of the solid compounds were performed at 25 °C on a 48000s (T-Optics) spectrofluorometer from SLM-Aminco. A front face sample holder was used for data collection and oriented at 60° to minimize light scattering from the excitation beam on the cooled R-928 photomultiplier tube. Appropriate filters were used to eliminate Rayleigh and Raman scattering from the emission. Excitation and emission spectra were corrected for the wavelength dependence of the 450 W xenon arc excitation but not for the wavelength dependence of the detection system. Spectroscopic properties were measured by reflection (front-face mode) on finely ground samples placed in quartz cells of 1 mm path length. No attempt was made to remove adsorbed or dissolved molecular oxygen from the materials. Reference samples (Rhodamine B) that do not contain any fluorescent dopant were used to check the background and optical properties of the samples.

elements.content: Single crystals of compounds 1–5 were mounted on glass fibers using a viscous hydrocarbon oil to coat the crystals. X-ray diffraction data collections and structure determinations were done at 100 K on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur (1) and at 296 K on a Bruker Kappa Apex II (4 and 5). In all cases the diffractometers were equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å).

elements.content: During the data reduction process it became clear that the selected crystal of compound 1 was a pseudomerohedric twin with a twin law: (1 0 0/0 1̅ 0/0.24 0 1). Compounds 1 and 2 were solved by direct methods using the SIR92 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 including all reflections (SHELXL97).All calculations were performed using the WINGX crystallographic software package. For compounds 4 and 5, the software package SHELXTL was used for space group determination, structure solution, and refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, completed with difference Fourier syntheses, and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 have been previously published. Crystal parameters and details of the final refinements of compounds 1, 4, and 5 are summarized in .

For compounds 4 and 5, the software package SHELXTL was used for space group determination, structure solution, and refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, completed with difference Fourier syntheses, and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystal structures of compounds 2  and 3  have been previously published. Crystal parameters and details of the final refinements of compounds 1, 4, and 5 are summarized in .

Density functional theory (DFT)-based calculations were performed by using the efficient plane-wave code QUANTUM ESPRESSO. In this atomistic simulation package the Kohn–Sham equations are solved using a periodic supercell geometry. The ion–electron interaction is modeled by ultrasoft pseudopotentials, and exchange-correlation (XC) effects are treated by the generalized-gradient-approximation (GGA) of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE). The one-electron wave functions are expanded in a basis of plane-waves with energy cut-offs of 400 and 500 eV for the kinetic energy and for the electronic density, respectively, which have been adjusted to achieve sufficient accuracy in the total energy. The Brillouin zones of the different bulk systems were sampled by using a k-space of Δk ≤ 0.01 Å–1.

elements.content: CuCl2·H2O (100 mg, 0.66 mmol) and ANP (160 mg, 1.15 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of water and ethanol (1:2). The suspension was stirred for 10 min at 25 °C and then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 4 days, and finally cooled down to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow crystals were isolated upon filtration; washed with water, ethanol, and diethyl ether; and dried under vacuum (40 mg, 29% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (found) for C5H5CuN3O2Cl: C, 25.22 (24.53); H, 2.12 (2.37); N, 17.65 (17.06). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3452 (m), 3347 (m), 1635 (s), 1603 (m), 1572 (m), 1332 (s), 1290 (s), 826 (m), 759 (w). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S1).

The suspension was stirred for 10 min at 25 °C and then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 4 days, and finally cooled down to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow crystals were isolated upon filtration; washed with water, ethanol, and diethyl ether; and dried under vacuum (40 mg, 29% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (found) for C5H5CuN3O2Cl: C, 25.22 (24.53); H, 2.12 (2.37); N, 17.65 (17.06). IR selected data (KBr, cm-1): 3452 (m), 3347 (m), 1635 (s), 1603 (m), 1572 (m), 1332 (s), 1290 (s), 826 (m), 759 (w). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S1).

elements.content: CuBr2 (50 mg, 0.22 mmol) and ANP (30 mg, 0.22 mmol) were suspended in 15 mL of water and ethanol (1:2). The suspension was stirred for 10 min at 25 °C and then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave heated using solvothermal microwave assisted activation, over 4 h at 160 °C and with slow cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 5.42 °C/h (24 h). A green solution was obtained with orange crystals in it. The orange crystals were isolated from the resulting green solution by filtration. The crystals were washed with a small amount of cold water, and dried with ethanol and diethyl ether (57 mg, 91.9% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C5H5CuN3O2Br: C, 21.25 (21.25); H, 1.78 (1.89); N, 14.87 (14.97). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3471 (m), 3328 (m), 1633 (s), 1601 (m), 1570 (m), 1334 (s), 1293 (s), 826 (m), 759 (w). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S2).

elements.content: CuCN (150 mg, 1.60 mmol) and ANP (233 mg, 1.60 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of CH3CN, and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h under constant magnetic stirring. The resulting yellow suspension was filtered off. The resulting solution was allowed to crystallize at 25 °C for a week. The resulting yellow crystals were washed with water, CH3CN, and diethyl ether and dried in air (270 mg, 70.4% based on Cu). Anal. elements.content: Although compounds 1–3 can be synthesized by direct reaction between CuX (X = Cl, Br, I) and the stoichiometric amount of ANP using solvothermal conditions, higher yields are obtained from the direct reactions carried out between the corresponding CuX2 (X = Cl, Br) salts and ANP under solvothermal or microwave conditions. During this process in situ Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) reduction reaction assisted by aromatic nitrogen ligands takes place under energetic conditions (Figures S1–S2). Indeed, this observation has been already reported for similar ligands. Note that the synthesis of compound 2 has recently been reported but without the characterization of its physical properties. The synthetic procedure is based on the reaction with CuBr·4H2O under solvothermal conditions for 4 days. Here we have observed that the use of solvothermal microwave assisted synthesis and CuBr2 instead of CuBr·4H2O results in a remarkable improvement of the yield going from 60% to 90%, and an important reduction of the synthesis time (from 4 days to 4 h). Similarly, the reaction carried out with CuCl led to formation of 1 however with lower yield than that using CuCl2 instead (16% vs 29% yield). Compound 3 has been previously prepared and characterized and is included here for comparison. Compounds 4 and 5 were directly obtained upon reaction of the corresponding CuX (X = SCN or CN) salts with ANP under mild conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Although compounds 1-3 can be synthesized by direct reaction between CuX (X = Cl, Br, I) and the stoichiometric amount of ANP using solvothermal conditions, higher yields are obtained from the direct reactions carried out between the corresponding CuX2 (X = Cl, Br) salts and ANP under solvothermal or microwave conditions. During this process in situ Cu(II) to Cu(I) reduction reaction assisted by aromatic nitrogen ligands takes place under energetic conditions (Figures S1-S2). Indeed, this observation has been already reported for similar ligands. Note that the synthesis of compound 2 has recently been reported but without the characterization of its physical properties. The synthetic procedure is based on the reaction with CuBr⋅4H2O under solvothermal conditions for 4 days. Here we have observed that the use of solvothermal microwave assisted synthesis and CuBr2 instead of CuBr⋅4H2O results in a remarkable improvement of the yield going from 60% to 90%, and an important reduction of the synthesis time (from 4 days to 4 h). Similarly, the reaction carried out with CuCl led to formation of 1 however with lower yield than that using CuCl2 instead (16% vs 29% yield). Compound 3 has been previously prepared and characterized and is included here for comparison. Compounds 4 and 5 were directly obtained upon reaction of the corresponding CuX (X = SCN or CN) salts with ANP under mild conditions.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 present a similar structural feature consisting of a double stranded stair motif () in which copper­(I) metal centers are bridged by μ3-halides. The tetrahedral coordination environment around the metal center is formed by three bridging halides, and the iminic nitrogen atom of the 2-amino-5-nitropyridine ligand (ANP). This chain motif shows the expected lengthening along the propagation direction (unit cell a edge) as the bridging halide size increases: 3.7060(2) Å for X = Cl (1), 3.7808(1) Å for X = Br (2), and 4.2284(1) Å for I (3). The copper–halide and copper–pyridine nitrogen bond distances are similar to those of other known [CuX­(L)] n stairs. collects the Cu–X, Cu–N, and Cu···Cu distances for compounds 1–3. The intrachain Cu···Cu distances found in these compounds are in many cases below the sum of the van der Waals radii (2.80 Å), indicating the presence of metallic Cu···Cu interactions that could explain the conductivity results found in some of these compounds (see below). The halide is tricoordinated in a distorted pyramidal geometry. The bond distance asymmetry decreases on going from chloride to iodide as can be seen in . The stair type chain can be also described as formed by planar Cu2X2 squares that share two opposite sides with dihedral angles in the range 98.7–105.3°. Surprisingly, the intrachain Cu–X–Cu and X–Cu–X angles do not show the expected increase as the size of X increases. Thus, these angles decrease from 104.9° to 98.7° when passing from Cl (1) to Br (2) and then increase to 105.3° for (3). This lack of size-angle trend indicates that in this series the halogen size is not the only factor determining the geometry of the chain and suggests that the packing forces and interchain interactions are also important in determining the structure of these compounds. This result supports the idea that the ANP ligand plays a crucial structural role and is, therefore, a good candidate to build DNA-templated structures. The ANP ligand is tilted and twisted relative to the propagation direction of the chain with tilt and twist angles in the ranges 78–90° and 55–68°, respectively. The chain cohesion is also ensured by the presence of π–π stacking interactions at each side of the chain between the adjacent ANP ligands with interplanar distances of 3.297 Å (1), 3.374 Å (2), 3.332 Å (3). Note again that these interplanar distances do not always follow the expected increase when the halogen size increases since the compounds are not isostructural and, as noted before, the Cu–X–Cu and X–Cu–X angles do not vary in a regular form. Additionally, all compounds show weak intrachain hydrogen bonds involving the halide as acceptor and the NH2/CH groups as donor thanks to the twisting of the ANP ligands.

Despite the great similarity between the chains of compounds 1–3, the overall crystal structure clearly shows the influence of the different hydrogen-bond acceptor capacity of the halides (). In compounds 1–3 the supramolecular architecture is directed by the hydrogen-bonding interactions established between the NH2 and C–H donor groups and the NO2 and halide acceptor groups of neighboring chains. In fact, the number of hydrogen-bond donor positions of the ANP ligand involved in the supramolecular hydrogen-bonding scheme reduces on going from 1 to 3, in agreement with the weaker hydrogen-bond acceptor capacity of the halides on going from chloride to iodide. shows selected distances and angles of the hydrogen-bonding interactions present in these compounds.

Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/n space group with cell parameters a = 14.6169(3) Å, b = 7.2367(2) Å, c = 16.1212(3) Å, and β = 110.554(1)°. Its crystal structure is formed by helical chains of formula [Cu­(ANP)­CN]∞ running parallel to the [100] direction (). The packing of these chains is accomplished through a dense net of hydrogen interactions involving the NO2 and NH2 groups from neighboring chains. The copper atoms within the same chain are located at longer distances than the ones found in compounds 1–3 due to the longer length of the CN bridge that coordinates in a linear Cu–CN–Cu mode: Cu1–Cu1 = 4.866 Å, Cu2–Cu2 = 4.930 Å, and Cu1–Cu2 = 4.946 Å. Some statistical disorder can be found in two of the three crystallographically independent CN groups acting as bridging ligands (involving atoms C12–N8 and C13–N9). It is worth noting that the crystal structure of an analogous 1D Cu­(I)–cyanide coordination polymer in which the ANP ligand is replaced by the 2,4,6-trimethylpyridine ligand, unable to establish hydrogen-bonding interactions, leads to a nonhelical zig-zag chain. This fact seems to indicate that the helical character of the chain of 4 is due to the requirements of the hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group with cell parameters a = 5.8985(1) Å, b = 14.2513(3) Å, c = 10.8843(2) Å, and β = 105.129(1)°. The crystal structure is formed by chains (, top) similar to the ones found in compounds 1–3 with the double stranded stair motif. In this case the copper­(I) metal centers are connected by μ3-1κN, 2:3κ2 S SCN bridges, where the sulfur atom is bridging two neighboring copper centers to form Cu2S2 squares, and the nitrogen atom is coordinated to a metal atom from another Cu2S2 square. This coordination mode gives rise to alternating long and short rectangles along the chain. The corresponding short and long Cu···Cu distances within the chain are 2.861 and 5.245 Å, much longer than the ones found in compounds 1–3 (). There are some other examples of this type of copper­(I)-thiocyanate double stranded stair motif, but in these cases the imine ligand is functionalized in order to act as a bridging ligand to increase the dimensionality of the resulting crystal structure.

elements.content: Two probe direct current (dc) electrical conductivity measurements at 300 K were performed in several single crystals of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5. The conductivity values at 300 K were obtained by applying voltages from +10 to −10 V. For complexes 1, 2, 4, and 5, the room-temperature average dc conductivity values are strongly dependent on the structure and on the bridging halogen atom. Thus, they vary in the range 10–8–10–12 S/cm (), suggesting in all cases that this family of polymers are semiconductors. In order to confirm this behavior and to determine their activation energies, we have performed dc conductivity measurements as a function of the temperature for at least four single crystals of each compound. These measurements show that compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5, with X = Cl, Br, CN, and SCN, respectively, display very similar thermal behaviors () with a decrease of the resistivity with increasing the temperature and following a classical Arrhenius law above ca. 350 K (inset in ). The activation energies determined for the four compounds (in the range 1.09–1.37 eV, ) are also very similar. At 400 K the conductivities reach values in the range 1 × 10–8 to 1 × 10–5 S/cm ().

Electrical Conductivity Studies

Two probe direct current (dc) electrical conductivity measurements at 300 K were performed in several single crystals of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5. The conductivity values at 300 K were obtained by applying voltages from +10 to -10 V. For complexes 1, 2, 4, and 5, the room-temperature average dc conductivity values are strongly dependent on the structure and on the bridging halogen atom. Thus, they vary in the range 10-8-10-12 S/cm (), suggesting in all cases that this family of polymers are semiconductors. In order to confirm this behavior and to determine their activation energies, we have performed dc conductivity measurements as a function of the temperature for at least four single crystals of each compound. These measurements show that compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5, with X = Cl, Br, CN, and SCN, respectively, display very similar thermal behaviors () with a decrease of the resistivity with increasing the temperature and following a classical Arrhenius law above ca. 350 K (inset in ). The activation energies determined for the four compounds (in the range 1.09-1.37 eV, ) are also very similar. At 400 K the conductivities reach values in the range 1 × 10-8 to 1 × 10-5 S/cm ().

In compounds 1–3 the conductivity values (Cl < Br < I) follow the expected order from orbital overlap considerations and Cu···Cu and Cu–X bond distances. However, the conductivity for the X = Br compound (2) is 1.5 times higher than that of the X = Cl (1) derivative whereas the X = I compound (3) is a significantly better conductor than 1 and 2. Furthermore, in the Br derivative the Cu–X bond distances are more regular than those in the Cl one, and therefore, its conductivity should be much better than that of the Cl compound. This unexpected small increase may be attributed to the significantly smaller Cu–X–Cu bond angle observed in the Br derivative (98.7°) compared with that observed in the Cl derivative (104.9°). On the other side, as expected, the X = I derivatives present the highest conductivity values since the orbital overlap is larger for X = I.

elements.content: In order to rationalize the electronic conductivity studies, we have carried out a set of first-principles density functional theory (DFT)-based calculations. For the theoretical simulations, we have used the structures obtained by X-ray diffraction. For all the polymers, the residual forces acting on each atom in all the calculations were below 0.1 eV/Å, which is low enough to guarantee perfectly converged and realistic results for such complex systems from a theoretical point of view. This noticeably good geometrical transferability between the experimental configurations and our theoretical implementation has already provided successful results for other similar CPs. The electronic structure calculations yield minimum values of the transport gaps at Γ points ranging between 0.59 and 1.52 eV for all the CPs (, ). It is important to remark on the excellent agreement between the experimental and theoretical activation energies. Theory can help to elucidate the semiconducting character of these materials.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

In order to rationalize the electronic conductivity studies, we have carried out a set of first-principles density functional theory (DFT)-based calculations. For the theoretical simulations, we have used the structures obtained by X-ray diffraction. For all the polymers, the residual forces acting on each atom in all the calculations were below 0.1 eV/Å, which is low enough to guarantee perfectly converged and realistic results for such complex systems from a theoretical point of view. This noticeably good geometrical transferability between the experimental configurations and our theoretical implementation has already provided successful results for other similar CPs. The electronic structure calculations yield minimum values of the transport gaps at Γ points ranging between 0.59 and 1.52 eV for all the CPs (, ). It is important to remark on the excellent agreement between the experimental and theoretical activation energies. Theory can help to elucidate the semiconducting character of these materials.

elements.content: Structural changes induced by external physical and/or chemical stimuli can produce a response in a given physical property based on the structural flexibility shown in previous Cu2X2 double chains, and in particular in the case of compound 3, which presents a variation in its electrical conductivity induced by several stimuli. Accordingly, we have decided to extend and compare our previous observations done in 3 with a similar halide bridged double chain polymer. Thus, since compounds 1 and 2 present quite similar conductivity values, we have selected 2 in order to study its electrical response versus vapors of several solvents and compare with that of 3. Pressed pellets of compounds 2 and 3 have been prepared and tested in saturated vapor atmospheres of several organic solvents. A simple prototype device was built and used for these measurements. The device consists of a pellet sample connected to two electrodes and cell used to expose the device to different organic vapors (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text:
Studies of the Electrical Respond to Several Organic Vapors

Structural changes induced by external physical and/or chemical stimuli can produce a response in a given physical property based on the structural flexibility shown in previous Cu2X2 double chains, and in particular in the case of compound 3, which presents a variation in its electrical conductivity induced by several stimuli. Accordingly, we have decided to extend and compare our previous observations done in 3 with a similar halide bridged double chain polymer. Thus, since compounds 1 and 2 present quite similar conductivity values, we have selected 2 in order to study its electrical response versus vapors of several solvents and compare with that of 3. Pressed pellets of compounds 2 and 3 have been prepared and tested in saturated vapor atmospheres of several organic solvents. A simple prototype device was built and used for these measurements. The device consists of a pellet sample connected to two electrodes and cell used to expose the device to different organic vapors (Figure S10).

elements.content: The initial ac conductivity values for the pristine pellets of both compounds are ca. 10–11 S/cm. After each time exposition, the samples were left in air for 30 min. In all the experiments, the solvent released, and the samples recovered the initial low conductivity values.
elements.clean_text: The initial ac conductivity values for the pristine pellets of both compounds are ca. 10-11 S/cm. After each time exposition, the samples were left in air for 30 min. In all the experiments, the solvent released, and the samples recovered the initial low conductivity values.

elements.content: In the experiments carried out with vapors of DMMP, (CH3CH2)2O, and CH2Cl2 no electrical change was measured for both 2 and 3 upon exposition for times up to 24 h. However, upon exposition of pellets of 2 and 3 to vapors of MeOH or HAcO, different responses were measured ( and Figure S11, respectively). In both cases the presence of MeOH produces a significant response in ca. 1 h enhancing the electrical conductivity ca. 2 orders of magnitude from the initial values. However, while in the case of 2 the electrical conductivity does not undergo any significant change with longer time exposition (14 and 24 h), 3 enhances its conductivity ca. 3.5 orders of magnitude up to 70 h (). Vapors of HAcO produce a similar effect in both compounds with an increase of their conductivity values of ca. 5 orders of magnitude upon 14 h of exposition (Figure S11). However, the response of compound 3 is faster and larger. Thus, compound 3 shows an increase of 4 orders of magnitude after ca. 15 min, whereas compound 2 needs more time and only increases 3 orders of magnitude. The faster and stronger response of 3 might be due to the shorter Cu–Cu distances found in its double chain and the higher flexibility and softness of the Cu2I2 double chain when compared with the Cu2Br2 one.

elements.content: New structural evidence shows that this strong chemical response is due to the hydrogen-bond interactions between the acetic acid molecules absorbed by the compound with the 2-amino-5-nitropyridine ligand (see compound 3a in SI, Tables S1 and S2 and Figures S5–S9). These interactions can slightly decrease the Cu–Cu and Cu–I distances resulting in a dramatic enhance of the conductivity.

elements.content: Compound 3 has also been exposed to vapors of EtOH using the same experimental conditions (). Ethanol also produces a response in the electrical conductivity of 3 increasing in ca. 2 orders of magnitude upon 1 h of exposition and more than 3 orders of magnitude after 14 h (). We observed that much longer times of exposure to ethanol vapors do not increase the electrical response but produce some disaggregation of the pellet, although without any chemical degradation.

elements.content: These results indicate that the interaction with H-bonding donor molecules such as HAcO, MeOH, or EtOH can induce structural changes in the Cu2X2 double chains shortening the Cu–Cu distances and/or enlarging the Cu–X–Cu bond angles leading to an increase in the electrical conductivity. Obviously, the adsorption should be essentially at the surface level of the pellet in a nonstructurally perfect organization since these are nonporous materials; accordingly, desorption takes place after they are again exposed to air for some time (30 min for 2 and 3), and they recover the initial conductivity values.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with aromatic ligands and d10 metal centers are very likely to exhibit fluorescence/luminescence. Therefore, the luminescent properties of Cu­(I) compounds (1–5) were investigated in the solid state, since the preparation of solutions were precluded by their insolubility. At room temperature, excitation of solid samples at λ = 380 and 425 nm produces very weak red emission with several peaks and maximum values centered at ca. 530, 624, and 687 nm, together with the characteristic bands due to transitions of the ANP ligand in the 450–520 nm range ().
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties Studies

Coordination polymers with aromatic ligands and d10 metal centers are very likely to exhibit fluorescence/luminescence. Therefore, the luminescent properties of Cu(I) compounds (1-5) were investigated in the solid state, since the preparation of solutions were precluded by their insolubility. At room temperature, excitation of solid samples at λ = 380 and 425 nm produces very weak red emission with several peaks and maximum values centered at ca. 530, 624, and 687 nm, together with the characteristic bands due to transitions of the ANP ligand in the 450-520 nm range ().

elements.content: Luminescent spectra of the free ligand (black), and the compounds 1 (orange), 2 (blue), 3 (green), 4 (pink), and 5 (deep green) (λexc = 380 nm).
elements.clean_text: 10  Luminescent spectra of the free ligand (black), and the compounds 1 (orange), 2 (blue), 3 (green), 4 (pink), and 5 (deep green) (λexc = 380 nm).

elements.content: In general, possible assignments for the excited states that are responsible the for emission of Cu­(I) complexes are ligand-centered π→ π* (LC) transitions, ligand-to-ligand (LLCT) transitions, ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transitions, metal-to-ligand (MLCT) transitions, charge-transfer transitions, or metal-centered d10 → d9s1 (MCC) transitions. The similarity between the emission spectra observed in the blue region between the ANP free ligand and the 1–5 complexes suggests that these transitions could be assigned to ligand-centered π → π* transitions and/or intraligand ones.
elements.clean_text: In general, possible assignments for the excited states that are responsible the for emission of Cu(I) complexes are ligand-centered π→ π* (LC) transitions, ligand-to-ligand (LLCT) transitions, ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transitions, metal-to-ligand (MLCT) transitions, charge-transfer transitions, or metal-centered d10 → d9s1 (MCC) transitions. The similarity between the emission spectra observed in the blue region between the ANP free ligand and the 1-5 complexes suggests that these transitions could be assigned to ligand-centered π → π* transitions and/or intraligand ones.

elements.content: The presence of a halide or pseudohalide in compounds 1–5 gives rise to weak low-energy red emissions that could be due to a triplet “cluster-centered” (CC) excited state and might be assigned to a combination of halide-to-metal charge-transfer (XMCT), and/or metal cluster-centered transitions [MCC, d Cu →(s,p) Cu]. The existence of an MCC contribution could be supported by the short Cu···Cu distances observed for compounds 1–3 and 5 (range: 2.764–2.861 Å), of the same order than twice the van der Waals radius of Cu (i.e., 2.8 Å) implying strong metal–metal interactions. However, compound 5, showing a similar spectrum but having larger Cu···Cu distances (d Cu···Cu = 4.866 Å), indicates that this MCC contribution does not have significant participation. In addition, the weaker emission observed for all complexes compared to that of the free ligand may indicate the participation of the halides in the emissive excited states, in the form of halide-to-metal charge-transfer (XMCT).
elements.clean_text: The presence of a halide or pseudohalide in compounds 1-5 gives rise to weak low-energy red emissions that could be due to a triplet "cluster-centered" (CC) excited state and might be assigned to a combination of halide-to-metal charge-transfer (XMCT), and/or metal cluster-centered transitions [MCC, d Cu →(s,p) Cu]. The existence of an MCC contribution could be supported by the short Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances observed for compounds 1-3 and 5 (range: 2.764-2.861 Å), of the same order than twice the van der Waals radius of Cu (i.e., 2.8 Å) implying strong metal-metal interactions. However, compound 5, showing a similar spectrum but having larger Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances (d Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu = 4.866 Å), indicates that this MCC contribution does not have significant participation. In addition, the weaker emission observed for all complexes compared to that of the free ligand may indicate the participation of the halides in the emissive excited states, in the form of halide-to-metal charge-transfer (XMCT).

elements.content: By direct reactions we have prepared a series of halide and pseudohalide Cu2X2 double chains with ANP as terminal ligand showing interesting electrical conductivity and emission. Electrical conductivity measurements show a strong dependence of the conductivity with the bridging ligand. All the coordination polymers presented in this work are semiconductors although they show remarkable experimental differences that have been explained using theoretical calculations. These results suggest that the use of theoretical calculations is a powerful tool for the design of new coordination polymers with desired electrical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By direct reactions we have prepared a series of halide and pseudohalide Cu2X2 double chains with ANP as terminal ligand showing interesting electrical conductivity and emission. Electrical conductivity measurements show a strong dependence of the conductivity with the bridging ligand. All the coordination polymers presented in this work are semiconductors although they show remarkable experimental differences that have been explained using theoretical calculations. These results suggest that the use of theoretical calculations is a powerful tool for the design of new coordination polymers with desired electrical properties.

elements.content: The capacity of these Cu2X2 double chains to respond to a chemical stimulus has been exemplified by the behavior observed in simple prototype devices prepared for compounds 2 and 3 consisting of pressed pellets contacted by two electrodes in a simple gas chamber. The electrical response of these materials to external stimuli has been attributed to two important features of their structure: (i) the structural flexibility of the double Cu2X2 chains due to the high polarizability of halide inducing significant changes in their electrical conductivity values, and (ii) the presence of ANP as terminal ligand directly connected to the Cu2X2 chains. The ANP ligand has amino and nitrosilo groups available for supramolecular H-bonding interactions with other guest molecules. Thus, ANP molecules tilt and twist in response to the presence of guest molecules affecting to the distances and angles of the Cu2X2 double chain and then to its electrical conductivity. In summary, the extraordinary sensitivity of the Cu2X2 double chains is due to the softness and dynamic character of the chains and to the presence of a ligand acting as an antenna for the chemical external stimuli. On the basis of a structural model of compound 3 with acetic acid (3a), we are confident that ANP acts as an antenna for the recognition of this donor molecule, and these interactions produce significant structural changes along the Cu2X2 chains shortening the Cu–Cu distances inducing an enhancement in their electrical conductivity values.

The ANP ligand has amino and nitrosilo groups available for supramolecular H-bonding interactions with other guest molecules. Thus, ANP molecules tilt and twist in response to the presence of guest molecules affecting to the distances and angles of the Cu2X2 double chain and then to its electrical conductivity. In summary, the extraordinary sensitivity of the Cu2X2 double chains is due to the softness and dynamic character of the chains and to the presence of a ligand acting as an antenna for the chemical external stimuli. On the basis of a structural model of compound 3 with acetic acid (3a), we are confident that ANP acts as an antenna for the recognition of this donor molecule, and these interactions produce significant structural changes along the Cu2X2 chains shortening the Cu-Cu distances inducing an enhancement in their electrical conductivity values.

elements.content: These preliminary studies suggest novel possibilities for the Cu2X2 chains bearing terminal ligands functionalized with selected groups able to selectively recognize molecules. For instance, we are now evaluating the ability of these double chains for the selective detection of organic molecules with H-bonding donor groups such as di- and trinitrophenols which are important industrial contaminants of soil near former explosive factories and military plants and/or closely related explosive or explosive-like molecules. Additionally, these results suggest that the exploration of materials based on novel Cu2X2 chains bearing different bridging ligands, e.g., azide, should be also considered.

cln_elements.content:
CuCl2·H2O (100 mg, 0.66 mmol) and ANP (160 mg, 1.15 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL of water and ethanol (1:2). The suspension was stirred for 10 min at 25 °C and then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 4 days, and finally cooled down to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow crystals were isolated upon filtration; washed with water, ethanol, and diethyl ether; and dried under vacuum (40 mg, 29% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (found) for C5H5CuN3O2Cl: C, 25.22 (24.53); H, 2.12 (2.37); N, 17.65 (17.06). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3452 (m), 3347 (m), 1635 (s), 1603 (m), 1572 (m), 1332 (s), 1290 (s), 826 (m), 759 (w). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S1).

Synthesis of [Cu­(C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>5</sub>N<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)­Br]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

CuBr2 (50 mg, 0.22 mmol) and ANP (30 mg, 0.22 mmol) were suspended in 15 mL of water and ethanol (1:2). The suspension was stirred for 10 min at 25 °C and then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave heated using solvothermal microwave assisted activation, over 4 h at 160 °C and with slow cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 5.42 °C/h (24 h). A green solution was obtained with orange crystals in it. The orange crystals were isolated from the resulting green solution by filtration. The crystals were washed with a small amount of cold water, and dried with ethanol and diethyl ether (57 mg, 91.9% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C5H5CuN3O2Br: C, 21.25 (21.25); H, 1.78 (1.89); N, 14.87 (14.97). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3471 (m), 3328 (m), 1633 (s), 1601 (m), 1570 (m), 1334 (s), 1293 (s), 826 (m), 759 (w). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cu­(C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>5</sub>N<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)­CN]<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>4</bold>)

CuCN (150 mg, 1.60 mmol) and ANP (233 mg, 1.60 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of CH3CN, and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h under constant magnetic stirring. The resulting yellow suspension was filtered off. The resulting solution was allowed to crystallize at 25 °C for a week. The resulting yellow crystals were washed with water, CH3CN, and diethyl ether and dried in air (270 mg, 70.4% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C6H5CuN4O2: C, 31.51 (30.70); H, 2.20 (2.56); N, 24.50 (23.95). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3439 (m), 3341­(m), 2114 (s), 1625 (s), 1573 (s), 1339 (s), 1285 (s). The purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S3).

Synthesis of {[Cu­(C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>5</sub>N<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)­SCN]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

CuSCN (75 mg, 0.62 mmol), ANP (85 mg, 0.61 mmol), and NH4SCN (140 mg, 1.84 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of CH3CN. The mixture was stirred for 3 h at 20 °C, and the resulting red solution was allowed to crystallize by slow evaporation of the solvent at 4 °C. Yellow crystals of complex 5 were formed after 2 weeks. The crystals were filtered off and washed with water, ethanol, acetonitrile, and diethyl ether and dried in air (115 mg, 73.7% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C6H5CuN4O2S: C, 27.64 (25.98); H, 1.93 (1.98); N, 21.49 (20.60); S, 12.30 (13.80). IR selected data (KBr, cm–1): 3438 (m), 3336 (m), 2165 (s), 1625 (s), 1572 (m), 1338 (s), 1288 (s). The purity of the sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S4).

cln_elements.content: Coordination polymers with aromatic ligands and d10 metal centers are very likely to exhibit fluorescence/luminescence. Therefore, the luminescent properties of Cu­(I) compounds (1–5) were investigated in the solid state, since the preparation of solutions were precluded by their insolubility. At room temperature, excitation of solid samples at λ = 380 and 425 nm produces very weak red emission with several peaks and maximum values centered at ca. 530, 624, and 687 nm, together with the characteristic bands due to transitions of the ANP ligand in the 450–520 nm range ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties Studies

Coordination polymers with aromatic ligands and d10 metal centers are very likely to exhibit fluorescence/luminescence. Therefore, the luminescent properties of Cu(I) compounds (1-5) were investigated in the solid state, since the preparation of solutions were precluded by their insolubility. At room temperature, excitation of solid samples at λ = 380 and 425 nm produces very weak red emission with several peaks and maximum values centered at ca. 530, 624, and 687 nm, together with the characteristic bands due to transitions of the ANP ligand in the 450-520 nm range ().
